doc.title: blast

description.text: The Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) finds regions of local similarity between sequences.

doc.authors: Altschul, Madden, Schaeffer, Zhang, Miller, Lipman

doc.title: PSI-Blast
doc.reference: Altschul, Stephen F., Thomas L. Madden, Alejandro A. Schaeffer,Jinghui Zhang, Zheng Zhang, Webb Miller, and David J. Lipman (1997), Gapped BLAST and PSI-BLAST: a new generation of protein database search programs, Nucleic Acids Res. 25:3389-3402.

interface.label: Start of required region in query (-S)

End of required region in query (-H)?
Location on query sequence. -1 indicates end of query

Protein database (-d )?
Choose a database Select Alu repeats from REPBASE nrprot: NCBI non-redundant Genbank CDS translations+PDB+Swissprot+PIR Protein Data Bank NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) Database last release NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) updates RefSeq (last release + updates) sbase: annotated domains sequences uniprot: Universal Protein Resource (sprot+treml) uniprot_sprot: Universal Protein Resource (SwissProt part) uniprot_trembl: Universal Protein Resource (TrEmbl part) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 90) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 50) Virus Pathogen Resource Genbank : Whole Genome Shotgun
Choose a protein db for blastp or blastx.

xhtml:div.label: Cost to open a gap (-G)

Cost to extend a gap (-E)?
Limited values for gap existence and extension are supported for these three programs. Some supported and suggested values are:
Existence Extension
10 -- 1
10 -- 2
11 -- 1
8 -- 2
9 -- 2
(source: NCBI Blast page)
Similarity matrix (-M) BLOSUM45 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM62 PAM30 PAM70

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This options also takes a string as an argument. One may use such a string to change the specific parameters of seg or invoke other filters. Please see the 'Filtering Strings' section (below) for details.

xhtml:div.label: Filter query sequence with SEG (-F) Yes No

Use lower case filtering (-U)?
Yes No
This option specifies that any lower-case letters in the input FASTA file should be masked.

Expected value (-e)?
The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.

Word Size (-W)?
Use words of size N.
Zero invokes default behavior
Default value: 3

Multiple hits window size (-A)?
When multiple hits method is used, this parameter defines the distance from last hit on the same diagonal to the new one.
Zero means single hit algorithm.

Threshold for extending hits (-f)?
Blast seeks first short word pairs whose aligned score reaches at least this value

X dropoff value for gapped alignment (-X)?
This is the value that control the path graph region explored by Blast during a gapped extension (Xg in the NAR paper).

X dropoff value for final gapped alignment (-Z)?
This parameter controls the dropoff for the final reported alignment. See also the -X parameter.

Dropoff for blast ungapped extensions in bits (-y)?
This parameter controls the dropoff at ungapped extension stage. See also the -X parameter.

Effective length of the search space (-Y)?
Use zero for the real size

Number of best hits from a region to keep (-K)?
If this option is used, a value of 100 is recommended.
Single-hit or multiple-hit mode (-P) Multiple-hit (0) Single-hit (1)
Number of bits to trigger gapping (-N)
Maximum number of passes to use in multipass version (-j)
e-value threshold for inclusion in multipass model (-h)

Constant in pseudocounts for multipass version (-c)?
This constant is the weight given to a pre-calculated residue target frequency (versus the observed one) in a column of the position specific matrix. The larger its value, the greater the emphasis given to prior knowledge of residue relationships vis a vis observed residue frequencies (beta constant in NAR paper).

Number of one-line descriptions to show? (-v)?
Maximum number of database sequences for which one-line descriptions will be reported.

Number of database sequences to show alignments? (-b)?
Maximum number of database sequences for which high-scoring segment pairs will be reported (-b).

Alignment view options (-m) Pairwise (0) Query-anchored showing identities (1) Query-anchored no identities (2) Flat query-anchored, show identities (3) Flat query-anchored, no identities (4) Query-anchored no identities and blunt ends (5) Flat query-anchored, no identities and blunt ends (6) XML Blast output (7) Tabular output (8)
Html output Yes No
Believe the query defline (-J) Yes No

SeqAlign file (-J option must be true) (-O)?
SeqAlign is in ASN.1 format, so that it can be read with NCBI tools (such as sequin). This allows one to view the results in different formats.

interface.label: Save PSI-Blast Matrix to file (-C)
Save PSI-BLAST Matrix as text to file (-Q)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The blastpgp program can do an iterative search in which sequences found in one round of searching are used to build a score model for the next round of searching. In this usage, the program is called Position-Specific Iterated BLAST, or PSI-BLAST. As explained in the accompanying paper, the BLAST algorithm is not tied to a specific score matrix. Traditionally, it has been implemented using an AxA substitution matrix where A is the alphabet size. PSI-BLAST instead uses a QxA matrix, where Q is the length of the query sequence; at each position the cost of a letter depends on the position w.r.t. the query and the letter in the subject sequence.

The position-specific matrix for round i+1 is built from a constrained multiple alignment among the query and the sequences found with sufficiently low e-value in round i. The top part of the output for each round distinguishes the sequences into: sequences found previously and used in the score model, and sequences not used in the score model. The output currently includes lots of diagnostics requested by users at NCBI. To skip quickly from the output of one round to the next, search for the string 'producing', which is part of the header for each round and likely does not appear elsewhere in the output. PSI-BLAST 'converges' and stops if all sequences found at round i+1 below the e-value threshold were already in the model at the beginning of the round.
Location on query sequence. -1 indicates end of query
Choose a protein db for blastp or blastx.
Limited values for gap existence and extension are supported for these three programs. Some supported and suggested values are:
Existence Extension
(source: NCBI Blast page)
This option specifies that any lower-case letters in the input FASTA file should be masked.

The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.
Use words of size N.
Zero invokes default behavior
Default value: 3
When multiple hits method is used, this parameter defines the distance from last hit on the same diagonal to the new one.
Zero means single hit algorithm.
Blast seeks first short word pairs whose aligned score reaches at least this value
This is the value that control the path graph region explored by Blast during a gapped extension (Xg in the NAR paper).
This parameter controls the dropoff for the final reported alignment. See also the -X parameter.
This parameter controls the dropoff at ungapped extension stage. See also the -X parameter.
Use zero for the real size
If this option is used, a value of 100 is recommended.

This constant is the weight given to a pre-calculated residue target frequency (versus the observed one) in a column of the position specific matrix. The larger its value, the greater the emphasis given to prior knowledge of residue relationships vis a vis observed residue frequencies (beta constant in NAR paper).
Maximum number of database sequences for which one-line descriptions will be reported.
Maximum number of database sequences for which high-scoring segment pairs will be reported (-b).
SeqAlign is in ASN.1 format, so that it can be read with NCBI tools (such as sequin). This allows one to view the results in different formats.

comment.text: The blastpgp program can do an iterative search in which sequences found in one round of searching are used to build a score model for the next round of searching. In this usage, the program is called Position-Specific Iterated BLAST, or PSI-BLAST. As explained in the accompanying paper, the BLAST algorithm is not tied to a specific score matrix. Traditionally, it has been implemented using an AxA substitution matrix where A is the alphabet size. PSI-BLAST instead uses a QxA matrix, where Q is the length of the query sequence; at each position the cost of a letter depends on the position w.r.t. the query and the letter in the subject sequence.

The position-specific matrix for round i+1 is built from a constrained multiple alignment among the query and the sequences found with sufficiently low e-value in round i. The top part of the output for each round distinguishes the sequences into: sequences found previously and used in the score model, and sequences not used in the score model. The output currently includes lots of diagnostics requested by users at NCBI. To skip quickly from the output of one round to the next, search for the string 'producing', which is part of the header for each round and likely does not appear elsewhere in the output. PSI-BLAST 'converges' and stops if all sequences found at round i+1 below the e-value threshold were already in the model at the beginning of the round.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The blastpgp program can do an iterative search in which sequences found in one round of searching are used to build a score model for the next round of searching. In this usage, the program is called Position-Specific Iterated BLAST, or PSI-BLAST. As explained in the accompanying paper, the BLAST algorithm is not tied to a specific score matrix. Traditionally, it has been implemented using an AxA substitution matrix where A is the alphabet size. PSI-BLAST instead uses a QxA matrix, where Q is the length of the query sequence; at each position the cost of a letter depends on the position w.r.t. the query and the letter in the subject sequence.

The position-specific matrix for round i+1 is built from a constrained multiple alignment among the query and the sequences found with sufficiently low e-value in round i. The top part of the output for each round distinguishes the sequences into: sequences found previously and used in the score model, and sequences not used in the score model. The output currently includes lots of diagnostics requested by users at NCBI. To skip quickly from the output of one round to the next, search for the string 'producing', which is part of the header for each round and likely does not appear elsewhere in the output. PSI-BLAST 'converges' and stops if all sequences found at round i+1 below the e-value threshold were already in the model at the beginning of the round.

comment.text: The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.

Expected value (-e)?
The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.
